text: Thank you. Thank you for the opportunity to present my submission today on Waipa District Council's representation review. Today my submission focuses on community boards, of which I do not support to be reinstated as part of this representation review. My submission is not based on personal opinions, interests, or spin. It is based on professional experience and the facts available.  So I believe you'll be presented with a well-balanced and fair perspective of why I believe WIPA is long overdue for a different representation model. So there are a few points I want to cover off. One, relevance. Two, purpose and linkages to outcomes. Three, layers of representation. Four, significance and engagement. And then I'll go into future options.  So let's start with some context and link that to relevance today. Community boards were created by LGNZ during the reform in 1989 out of concern that some of the amalgamated councils would be so large that former communities of interest might lose representation. Community boards were used to enable democratic local decision-making on behalf of communities. More than 30 years later, we're still using the same model.  Waipa is still relatively small in size and population compared to other districts and cities, yet everyone has equal opportunity to take part in local government decision-making in a way that best suits them. In 2021, to successfully engage with communities today, you must take a multi-channel approach to get cut through an increasingly more complex communication environment. This usually includes a mixture of things like media, owned channels, so that  Examples are your website, social media networks, newsletters, meetings, presentations and that sort of thing. And then paid media like digital and print advertising and campaigns. These are just a few examples and in Council's case, a community board meeting, community board is one piece of your complex engagement puzzle. However, when you weigh up community boards as a community engagement tool alongside other ways to engage, the people cost is high and they require significant supplementary resource to facilitate  at each meeting, for example, staff time, advertising, and so on. From my professional experience, community boards lack the level of influence today that they potentially had 10 years ago, let alone 30 years ago. And there is plenty of evidence available to show you that Waipou residents and ratepayers engage in local government decision-making using other techniques and approaches that are far less resource intensive.  So now I'd like to touch on the purpose of community boards. One of the key questions I wanted you to answer was, what do community boards do? You answered this on your website of 12 questions, that was number 10 on the list. Purpose was vaguely described and failed to connect to any robust way to performance measures or outcomes. Looking through the consultation information, you focus on numbers, boundaries, and names, but did not provide anything substantial on whether community boards are still relevant today  Do they empower community engagement? Are they making a difference in Waipā? Are they achieving what Council set out for them to achieve? Are community boards meeting the ever more complex two-way communication needs of communities? And are community boards meeting residents' and ratepayers' expectations? Are they providing value for money?  What's concerning here is that in your latest resident survey, almost half of residents surveyed said they didn't know what community boards do. Timing wise, you probably had these results and there was an opportunity to address this when asking the community to have their say. Yet you skipped over this in your consultation with ads and social media posts prompting people to provide feedback on numbers and boundaries with no context or mention of what community boards do and why.  and what they achieve. Essentially, I would actually argue that this makes the quantitative data presented in the report in relation to the 49 submitters unusable because you haven't provided enough information to the public to give their feedback. I said in my written submission that because people don't know what communities  community boards do that I expected your response to this consultation process would be quite low and I was correct. The numbers actually do fail to provide a true reflection of what the community knows about community boards or thinks about community boards and without tangible substantial answers to the questions I've raised in my submission I can't see how you could hand on heart with confidence  say that community boards were a valuable asset to the Waipa community and that they should be reinstated for the next year's election. My third point was around layers of representation. In the consultation material, it states, quote, community boards are an additional layer of representation that support directly to council. And the key word here is layer, which in local government can often imply unnecessary complexity, inefficiency,  and sometimes a painful customer experience. If you did a stock take, you'd find that the responsibilities of community boards, as broadly set out in the legislation, are already carried out by the mayor, councillors, the council executive, and their staff. More specifically, you have made a significant investment into facilitating community engagement and consultation activities year on year that are carried out by permanent staff.  You have to, because it is a legislative requirement. You have a comms team, you have newly appointed community advisors working at the front line, grassroots level, to improve the linkages between council and communities. You have iwi advisors, and there are other stakeholder managers. There are many layers. The community board layer, from my perspective, is unnecessary. It is adding complexity, it is inefficient. And as one submitter pointed out,  the meetings are too formal and can be off-putting for members of the public anyway. Surely if a resident or ratepayer wants to discuss an idea, raise an issue or a concern, a direct line of communication to a councillor or a relevant council staff member would be their preferred option. It's certainly my preferred option and that's why I'm talking to you today.  So my fourth point was in relation to your Significance and Engagement Policy, which I did notice was not addressed in the report to the committee, and this may have been an oversight. Council's Significance and Engagement Policy was updated four months ago as part of the LTP, following consultation with the community. This policy outlines how Council will fulfil its legislative requirement to successfully engage and consult with the community under Section 5 of the Local Government Act 2002.  It also outlines the framework for how council will inform, consult, involve, collaborate with, and empower communities to take part in local government decision making. The policy makes absolutely no mention of using community boards as a mechanism to fulfill this legislative requirement.  Even if this was an oversight, you have to ask yourself why no one thought about community boards being at least mentioned in this framework. What the policy does demonstrate, however, is that today the community has never been more empowered to engage with council, and there are many different ways to do this.  So in my last point, in terms of future options and how you can attract and retain elected members, perhaps the real opportunity here is to tighten up the total number of elected members, i.e. remove community boards, which could help to attract a wider pool of candidates to council. And as a Cambridge resident, I would like to see a strong calibre of candidates to vote for, and there are potentially elected community board members who could represent my views at the council table.  I did notice that another submitter, who's just spoken, provided an alternative option. And it is clear that there are other ways of doing things that would achieve the right outcomes. Discretionary funding, for example, could be allocated by an existing council appointed funding committee to make this process a lot fairer and more transparent. I do have to note, too, that if your community board model was fit for purpose, you wouldn't be setting up a committee following the Streets for People trial  to represent the community's views on cycling in Cambridge. Again, added layers. So I'll leave it there. I sincerely hope this feedback is considered and it encourages some more vigorous debate around if the community board model of 1989 still meets the needs of our communities in 2021 and beyond. Thanks.
